metadata.title: Effect of alkylaluminium on the regio- and stereoselectivity in copolymerization of isoprene and butadiene using TiCl<ce:inf loc=post>4</ce:inf>/MgCl<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> type Ziegler-Natta catalyst

Effect of alkylaluminium on the regio- and stereoselectivity in copolymerization of isoprene and butadiene using TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalyst Qingtao Niu a Junying Zhang a Wei Peng a Zhiqiang Fan b Aihua He a ⁎ a Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, Shandong, 266042, China Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education) School of Polymer Science and Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China b MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization, Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization Department of Polymer Science and Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Alkylaluminium compounds with smaller alkyl group size showed higher copolymerization activity, higher reducing ability and then yielding more active center numbers ([C*]/[Ti]) in the order TEA > TiBA > DiBAH > DEAC. The copolymers obtained during the very initial period were the mixtures of cis-1,4 units and trans-1,4 units structures and then transformed to highly trans-1,4 structure, indicating a transformation of the active center nature during the early polymerization stage, which can be accelerated effectively through the addition of DEAC into the TiCl4/MgCl2-TEA catalyst system. Alkylaluminums as one of the most important components of the heterogeneous MgCl2-supported (TiCl4/MgCl2) type Ziegler-Natta catalysts, play significant roles in yielding active species with varied regio- and stereoselectivity. Studying the contribution of alkylaluminums on the conjugated diene isoprene (Ip) and butadiene (Bd) copolymerizations with TiCl4/MgCl2 - alkylaluminum catalysts system is little reported. In this work, effects of various alkylaluminums including triethylaluminium (TEA), triisobutylaluminium (TiBA), diisobutylaluminium hydride (DiBAH) and diethylaluminum chloride (DEAC) on the copolymerization behaviors of Ip and Bd using the TiCl4/MgCl2 - alkylaluminum catalysts system, such as catalytic activity, active center numbers, butadiene incorporation, trans-1,4 stereoselectivity, molecular weight M w as well as molecular weight distribution M w/M n of copolymers were first investigated. TEA with smaller size ethyl groups showed higher copolymerization activity, higher reducing ability and then yielding more active center numbers ([C*]/[Ti]) when compared with TiBA, DiBAH and DEAC. Microstructure of copolymers gradually transformed from the cis-1,4/trans-1,4 mixed structure in the initial polymerization period to the finally high trans-1,4 structure, indicating a transformation of the active center nature during the early polymerization stage, which can be accelerated effectively through the addition of DEAC into the TiCl4/MgCl2-TEA catalyst system. TEA with smaller size ethyl group showed higher transformation rate from the mixed structures of trans-1,4 and cis-1,4 to highly trans-1,4 structure. The active center numbers of the copolymerization systems increased gradually with increasing time until reaching a stable level. The M w/M n of copolymers showed interesting evolution with increasing polymerization time from broad distribution with low to medium molecular weight fractions in the initial polymerization stage to relatively narrow distribution with high molecular weight fractions. The contribution of alkylaluminium compounds on the structure of active species which determining the regio- and stereoselectivity of Ip and Bd copolymerization using heterogeneous TiCl4/MgCl2 type catalysts were discussed in details Keywords Alkylaluminum Trans-1,4 Ip and Bd copolymerization TiCl4/MgCl2 type 1 Introduction As the most important industrial catalysts for olefin polymerizations, the heterogeneous MgCl2-supported (TiCl4/MgCl2) type Ziegler-Natta catalysts have the perfect combination of the catalytic activity, the stereoregularity and the polymer particle morphology control [1–3]. However, the active species and catalytic mechanism of TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts are still very mysterious owing to the difficulties in identifying the trace heterogeneous active species blanketed by the abundances of MgCl2, low Ti content, easy deactivation of active species, the complex and reversible reactions among alkylaluminium, TiCl4 and MgCl2 and so on [4–12]. For the polymerization of olefins using the TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts, alkylaluminum compounds as cocatalyst strongly influence the catalytic behaviors such as polymerization activity, stereoselectivity, active center transformation and numbers, Ti-specie oxidation state and distribution, polymer molecular weight M w as well as molecular weight distribution M w/M n. Various works have been done to investigate the special roles of alkylaluminum as cocatalyst in olefin polymerizations using TiCl4/MgCl2-alkylaluminum catalysts system. Roles of alkylaluminum contain the reduction reaction of TiCl4 on catalyst surface to lower oxidation state as well as subsequent alkylation reaction of Ti species to generate active centers [13–15]. Al-arifi [16] and Bresadola [17] reported that TiII and TiIII species were both active in the polymerization of ethylene, TiIII were active in the polymerization of propylene. Active center model regarding the special role of alkylaluminum cocatalyst in the heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalysts has been firstly discussed in 1966 by Rodriguez [18], and bi-metal model and single-metal model have been developed [19–30]. Recently, Busico and his workers [23–25] reported a three-site model including the interconversion among the syndiospecific center, poorly isopecific center, highly isopecific center. Based on the model, Terano et al. [26,27] further clarified the substantial roles of alkylaluminum cocatalysts on the formation and transformation of stereospecific active centers though absorbing and complexing on catalyst surface. 27Al NMR MAS studies by Potapov et al. [28,29] concluded that the aluminium absorbing and complexing on supported TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts surface was mainly dialkylaluminum chloride. Fan [30] further reported that dialkylaluminum chloride such as diethylauminum chloride DEAC can also change the stereoselectivity and activity of propylene polymerization by complexing with Mg or Ti atoms on catalyst surface. Cipullo [31] and Fan [32] also found the co-adsorption of Al-alkyl (DEAC) and donors on catalyst surface enhancing the lateral steric pressure and surface coverage and improving the stereoselectivity of active centers. Yoon [33] found that using other alkylaluminum compounds than triethylaluminum (TEA) usually caused lower isotacticity and lower catalyst activity of propylene polymerization. Terano [34] found that the active center numbers reduced drastically as alkyl size of trialkylaluminum increased, lower activation capacity of diethylauminum chloride DEAC was due to the fewer Ti active species formed by diethylauminum chloride DEAC. The M w and M w/M n of the resulting polypropylenes decreased as the alkyl size increased in cocatalyst which was ascribed to the more obvious reducing capacity of Ti species from cocatalyst with smaller alkyl group. Bresadola [17] reported that the dependence of oxidation state distribution of Ti species on alkyluminum concentration in ethylene and propylene polymerization. Yoon [33] also reported that M w and M w/M n of obtained PP using TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst increased as alkyl groups size increased in alkylaluminum cocatalyst due to the efficiency of alkylaluminum used as the molecular chain transfer regent depending on the local steric environment hindrance of alkyl group [35]. Although great efforts have been done to study the contribution of alkylaluminum cocatalyst on α-olefin polymerization, few details are reported on the special roles of alkylaluminum compounds on Ip and Bd copolymerization catalyzed by TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts. Coordination polymerization mechanism of conjugated dienes is totally different from α-olefins [36–42], the transition-metal-catalyzed conjugated diene polymerization is a π-allyl-insertion, and the terminal group of growing chain bonded to transition metal exists in anti-allyl group and syn-allyl group, which will yield cis-1,4 structure units and trans-1,4 structure units, respectively. Trans-1,4-Poly(isoprene-co-butadiene) copolymer (TBIR) chain structures including chain microstructure, M w and M w/M n, comonomer incorporation and dyad sequence distribution will greatly influence the performances of the materials [43–45], which are determined by the active species with different rigo- and stereoselectivity [9,10]. Our previous works [9,10] reported a transformation of stereoselectivity of active center from the low trans-1,4 stereoselectivity during the initial copolymerization period to the high trans-1,4 stereoselectivity as the copolymerization time increased in butadiene and isoprene copolymerization using TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst activated with TiBA. In this paper, effects of alkylaluminums including TEA, TiBA, DiBAH and DEAC on regio- and stereoselectivity in the copolymerization of Ip and Bd using TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst were studied for the first time. Catalytic activity, active center numbers and transformation, polymer microstructure (trans-1,4/cis-1,4), comonomer butadiene incorporation (FBd), M w as well as M w/M n of the copolymers were also investigated. The possible structure and transformation of active species activated with different alkylaluminiums with different catalytic behaviors were discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical The lab-made TiCl4/MgCl2 type Zeigler-Natta catalyst (Ti content was 2 wt%) was used for copolymerization. Triethylaluminium (TEA, 3.3 mol/L in n-heptane), triisobutylaluminium (TiBA, 3.9 mol/L) and diisobutylaluminium hydride (DiBAH, 5.5 mol/L) were supplied by the Yanshan Petrochemical Company, China. Diethylaluminum chloride (DEAC, 2.0 mol/L in hexane) was supplied by J&K Chemicals Co. Isoprene was purchased from the Chambroad petrochem Company and distilled under the reduced pressure. Butadiene (purchased from the Shandong Huaju Polymer Materials Company) was first distilled and then purified with the molecular sieve. 2-Thiophenecarbonyl chloride TPCC was supplied by J&K Chemicals Company and distilled. The n-heptane and the toluene were purified by the reflux extraction method over Na/benzophenone. 2.2 Copolymerization and quenching reaction A series of solution copolymerizations of isoprene and butadiene in toluene with a weight ratio of monomer (M)/toluene = 50/50 were carried out in the 100 mL round bottomed flasks by using magnetic stirrer. The purged and vacuumed flask was added about 80 mL monomer-toluene mixture containing a constant molar ratio of butadiene/isoprene = 0.5/99.5. Calculated amount of alkylaluminium was added into flask and the copolymerization started as TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst was added into flask at 30 °C. After a predetermined copolymerization time, the copolymerization was quenched though injecting TPCC (TPCC/Al = 3 mol/mol) into reaction flask at 50 °C for 5 min. And then an excess of alcohol with 2 vol% HCl was added into flask to terminate polymerization reaction. The copolymer was precipitated and washed with an excess of alcohol thrice, then dried for 24 h in a vacuum drying oven at 45 °C. Some copolymer samplers were further purified to measure the active center number by the following process: (1) The samples were first refluxed in alcohol containing 2 wt% anti-aging agent 2,6-Di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (264) for 1 h, and the polymer samples were precipitate by alcohol; (2) The polymer samples obtained from (1) were further dissolved in the toluene containing 2 wt% anti-aging agent 2,6-Di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol and precipitated and dried again; (3) The polymer samples obtained from (2) were further extracted by alcohol containing 2 wt% anti-aging agent 2,6-Di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol with the Soxhlet extractors for 12 h, and dried at 40 °C in vacuum. 2.3 Fractionation procedure of TBIR copolymer Based on our previous works [10,46], the resulted TBIR copolymers with TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst were fractionated by stepwise isothermal crystallization fractionations method. About 0.30 g of TBIR copolymer was dissolved in the n-heptane/toluene (80 mL/20 mL) mixed solvent at 80 °C for 2 h. After filtration, the insoluble part (IS-1) and soluble part (S) were obtained. (1) The IS-1 was further dissolved with xylene for 1 h at 120 °C and then separated into the soluble part and insoluble part, which were named as Fraction A and Fraction I, respectively. (2) The soluble part (S) at 80 °C was subsequently cooled down to 20 °C for isothermal crystallization for 24 h, after filtration, the insoluble part was named as Fraction B, and the remaining transparent solution was again cooled down to 10 °C for isothermal crystallization for 24 h, after filtration, the insoluble part was named as Fraction C. With repeating the above process, the insoluble parts after isothermal crystallization for 24 h under 0 °C, -10 °C and -20 °C were named as Fraction D, Fraction E, Fraction F, respectively. Finally, the soluble part at -20 °C was named as Fraction G. 2.4 Characterization 1H-NMR spectra of copolymers were characterized with the Bruker spectrometer (500 MHz) in Chloroform-d (CDCl3) with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as standard at 25 °C. The polymers microstructure molar content and butadiene unit molar percentage (FBd) were calculated based on 1H-NMR [46]. M w as well as M w/M n of the copolymers were characterized by the HLC-8320GPC gel permeation chromatography at 40 °C with tetrahydrofuran and calibrated by the polystyrene standards. Active center numbers ([C∗]/[Ti]) of TiCl4/MgCl2 - alkylaluminum were characterized though determining the sulfur contents in TPCC quenched copolymers by a ultraviolet fluorescence detector (YHTS-2000, Taizhou Yinhe Instrument Co.). Three parallel measurements of quenched copolymer samples were carried out and the average value was taken. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic behaviors of TiCl4/MgCl2-alkylaluminum A series of copolymerizations of Ip and Bd using TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts activated by triethylaluminum (TEA), triisobutylaluminum (TiBA), diisobutylaluminium hydride (TiBAH), diethylaluminumchloride (DEAC) in different Al/Ti ratios were carried out. The dependence of the catalytic behaviors of the TiCl4/MgCl2-alkylaluminium catalysts such as catalytic activity, microstructure (trans-1,4/cis-1,4), comonomer incorporation (FBd), M w as well as M w/M n of the copolymers on the copolymerization time ranging from 1 min to 120 min were firstly investigated. 3.1.1 Catalytic activity and active centers numbers Table 1 and Fig. 1 (a,c) showed that both the monomer conversion and catalytic efficiency of the copolymerizations with TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst activated by alkylaluminium compounds increased gradually as the copolymerization time increased from t = 1 min to t = 60 min. The monomer conversion and catalytic efficiency increased drastically in the order of TEA > TiBA > DiBAH > DEAC. Increasing alkylaluminum concentration from Al/Ti = 30 (mol/mol) to Al/Ti = 50 (mol/mol), the monomer conversions were notably enhanced (Run 19–21 in Table 1). Trace oligomers were produced with DEAC as cocatalyst as Table 1 shown. The active center number [C*]/[Ti] in the isoprene and butadiene copolymerization system was measured though determining the sulfur concentration of the quenched copolymer formed by the quenching reaction between the quenching agent TPCC and the active center [30,47]. The [C*]/[Ti] first increased gradually as the copolymerization time increased during the initial 15 min and then levelled off to a steady level (Table 1 and Fig. 1(c)). The steady active center number in the copolymerization system was in the order of TEA > TiBA > DiBAH, which can explain the different catalytic behaviors of the TiCl4/MgCl2-alkylaluminum system. TEA with small ethyl groups had higher reducing and alkylating ability to generate more active centers (13 mol% of the overall titanium). Increasing alkylaluminum concentration from Al/Ti = 30 (mol/mol) to Al/Ti = 50 (mol/mol) led to an obvious increasing of the active center number of the copolymerization system as shown in Table 1. 3.1.2 Microstructure and butadiene units content The evolution of butadiene incorporation molar percentage (FBd) and microstructure (trans-1,4, cis-1,4) molar percentage of the copolymer activated with different alkylaluminium compounds with the increase in conversion were shown in Table 1 and Fig. 2 . The FBd showed a rapid climbing up to the maximum value and then gradually reduced as the monomer conversion increased. In the initial polymerization time (1% conversion), the FBd in copolymer reached the highest value and showed the order of TEA > DiBAH > TiBA, which indicated that smallest alkyl group in the alkylaluminium contributed to most butadiene incorporation in copolymer chain, and also led to the most rapid decrease in the FBd with polymerization time increasing. The microstructure of copolymers formed during initial copolymerization time with TiCl4/MgCl2 - alkylaluminium systems were the mixed structure of trans-1,4 and cis-1,4, then trans-1,4 structure content gradually increased and finally became the dominant (about 97˜99 mol%) at about 3 wt% conversion, which indicated a transformation of active centers from low trans-1,4 to great high trans-1,4 stereoselectivity as copolymerization time increased. Copolymers activated with TEA showed a little faster structure transformation to higher trans-1,4 units content when compared with other alkylaluminiums. We attributed this phenomenon to the more rapid complexation and absorption reaction between the by-product AlEt2Cl and active species on catalyst surface to form the species with higher trans-1,4 stereoregularity [10]. 3.1.3 Polymer molecular weight and MWD M w as well as MWD of copolymers obtained at different polymerization time presented an interesting evolution (Table 1). The M w of copolymers gradually increased from low M w (3.3 × 105, Run 1 in Table 1,1 min) obtained in the very initial polymerization stage to high M w (31.5 × 105, Run 6 in Table 1) after 60 min polymerization time, and MWD gradually narrowed from 7.4 to 10.2 (Run 1–4 in Table 1, 1–15 min) to 3.4 (Run 6 in Table 1, 60 min). The peak fitting was conducted on the GPC curves of copolymers and different Flory peaks reflecting different molecular weight fractions were obtained (Fig. 3 ). This Flory peak fitting has been proved to be a useful and reliable method to study the multiple active centers of TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts [48–50] and every Flory component represented one kind of active centers. The numbers of Flory components were used to appraise active centers distribution. The numbers of Flory components from TEA and TiBA gradually reduced with increasing polymerization time, which was reflected by the reducing of low M w components as well as the increasing of high M w components, and finally the high M w components became the dominant components. The results indicated that the active centers distribution changed continually with the increasing copolymerization reaction time, and active centers undergone a transformation from low stereoregular ones generating low M w polymer chains to high stereoregular ones generating high M w polymer chains with increasing polymerization time. Finally the high stereoregular active centers became the dominant. The M w of copolymers obtained with DiBAH also showed the similar tendency. 3.1.4 Fractionation and fraction of copolymer The isothermal crystallization fractionation technique in the temperature range of 120 °C ˜ −20 °C was utilized to isolate the fractions in copolymers activated with TEA [10,46]. As shown in Table 2 , the copolymers synthesized at initial 1 min with 0.04 wt% conversion were mainly composed of low trans-1,4 structure fraction G with relatively low molecular weight and broad MWD, and high trans-1,4 structure fractions like D and E with relatively high molecular weight and narrow MWD. As the copolymerization time increased from t = 1 min to t = 60 min, low trans-1,4 structure fraction G content gradually reduced from 9.5 wt% to 2.0 wt%, while high trans-1,4-structure fractions including D and E contents gradually increased from 21.0 wt% and 10.7 wt% to 71.0 wt% and 17.0 wt%, respectively, and finally D and E became the main components. The trans-1,4 content of fraction G also increased with increasing polymerization time. These results indicated that the Fraction G was generated from low trans-1,4 stereoselectivity active center with features like low molecular weight and complex multi-sites, while Fraction D and E were generated from the high trans-1,4 stereoselectivity active centers with higher molecular weight feature. A transformation from low trans-1,4 stereoselectivity active centers to high trans-1,4 stereoselectivity actives could interplay the evolution of the fraction components with different microstructure and molecular weight with increasing polymerization time. 3.2 Catalytic behaviors of TiCl4/MgCl2-TEA/DEAC The specific roles of DEAC in the formation and transformation of trans-1,4 isospecific active sites in Ip and Bd copolymerization using the TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst were shown in Table 3 . As the molar ratio of DEAC/Ti increased from 0 to 10, the trans-1,4 structure molar content of isoprene unit of copolymers obtained at 2 min was increased from 74.6 mol% to 84.4 mol% (Run 1 to 5, Table 3). Therefore, during the very initial copolymerization period, DEAC engaged in active center formation to promote the active centers transformation from the low stereoregularity to the high stereoregularity. Therefore, a longer polymerization time (30 min, Run 6–10) led to a slightly increase in the trans-1,4 content. While a decreased conversion was observed for DEAC/Ti = 10 (Run 10, Table 3). These results demonstrated that an appropriate amount of DEAC with DEAC/Ti = 2 will help to yield copolymers with effectively improved trans-1,4 stereoselectivity of some active centers without any obvious decrease in catalytic efficiency. However, excess DEAC can lead to a decreased conversion of the copolymerization reflecting the inactivation of the active centers but also partly deactivated some active centers. The M w/M n of copolymer was narrowed with the introduction of DEAC into TiCl4/MgCl2-TEA catalyst system indicating the change in active center distribution, while the butadiene incorporation in the copolymers changed little. 3.3 Plausible models of the active center structures of the TiCl4/MgCl2-alklyaluminum (AlR3) catalyst system The contribution mechanism of alkylaluminum compounds in TiCl4/MgCl2-alklyaluminum (AlR3) catalyst system catalyzing isoprene and butadiene copolymerization was proposed in Scheme 1 . Firstly, the chemical activity of the alklyaluminum (AlR3) was TEA > TiBA > y ¨ DiBAH > y ¨ DEAC. As the most active alkylaluminum, TEA reacted with TiCl4/MgCl2 through alkylation and reduction reactions to form much more active centers C*-1 in much shorter time. Active centers C*-1 with the features such as low steric hindrance and different structures on various defects of MgCl2 allowed the insertion of isoprene and butadiene monomers with the s-cis conformation to generated the cis-1,4 polymer chains [51–53]. The cis-1,4 and trans-1,4 mixed structures, broad polymer chain component distribution as well as broad molecular weight distribution indicated the complex muti-site structures of C*-1. The easy chain transfer reaction of C*-1 with low steric hindrance led to the copolymer with low molecular weight. In addition, the dynamically stable anti-ally groups in active centers C*-1 undergone the transformation to thermodynamically stable syn-allyl groups to generate cis-trans linkage in polymer chains [9,10]. Secondly, DEAC, generated from the reaction between AlR3 and TiCl4 on catalyst surface, can complex with the Mg atoms on adjacent metal Ti of C*-1 by two Cl bridges which led to the active centers transformation from C*-1 to C*-2. Active centers C*-2 had high crowded steric environment allowing the insertion of isoprene and butadiene monomers with the s-trans conformation to form trans-1,4 polymer chains [51–53]. Therefore, an appropriate amount of DEAC with DEAC/Ti = 2 mol/mol was good for the C*-2 formation and helped the copolymerization system to form highly trans-1,4 copolymers. Parallelly, the DEAC can also complex with central Ti of the active centers C*-1 to lead to some deactivation of partial active centers C*-1, which can explain the decreased conversion with more DEAC addition in the copolymerization system. A stable active-center-number formation needed about 15 min at 30 °C indicating the reaction between TiCl4 and AlR3 was diffusion control. However, the first 15 min was not enough for C*-2 formation, which can be reflected by the longer time needed for high trans-1,4 unit formation. Anyway, TEA as the most active aluminium compound needed the shortest time for the C*-2 formation. The ethyl group in C*-1 from TEA with higher reactivity benefited more butadiene incorporation in copolymer chains. 4 Conclusion The catalytic behaviors of TiCl4/MgCl2-alkylaluminum catalyst system catalyzing Ip and Bd copolymerization activated by alkylaluminum compounds were strongly influenced by the types of alkylaluminum. Alkylaluminum with smaller alkyl groups facilitated higher polymerization activity, more comonomer butadiene incorporation and more active centers formation. The structures of copolymers obtained through activation by TEA or TiBA or DiBAH in the very initial stage were the trans-1,4 units and cis-1,4 units mixed structures, then gradually transformed to highly trans-1,4 structures as the copolymerization reaction time increased. TEA with the smaller ethyl groups showed higher microstructure transformation rate of copolymers from the mixed structures of cis-1,4 units and trans-1,4 units to highly trans-1,4 units structures when compared with TiBA and DiBAH. The active center numbers of the copolymerization systems gradually increased with increasing time until reaching a stable level after 15 min. The M w/M n of copolymers showed an interesting evolution with increasing polymerization time from broad distribution with low to medium molecular weight fractions in the initial polymerization stage to relatively narrow distribution with high molecular weight fractions. Upon the alkylation and reduction reactions between alkylaluminum and TiCl4 on catalyst surface, various active centers C*-1 with features such as low steric hindrance and easy chain transfer generated copolymers with mixed configuration of cis-1,4 structure and trans-1,4 structure, higher butadiene incorporation as well as broad MWD. DEAC generated from the reaction between AlR3 and TiCl4 can complex with the Mg atoms on adjacent central metal Ti atoms of active centers C*-1 by two Cl bridges causing the active center transformation from C*-1 to C*-2. Active center C*-2 with highly crowded steric environment and difficult chain transfer allowed isoprene and butadiene monomer insertion in s-trans to form copolymers with high content of trans-1,4 configuration as well as high M w. An appropriate amount of DEAC can effectively improve trans-1,4 stereoselectivity of active centers, while the excess DEAC can also complex with the central Ti of active centers C*-1 to lead to the deactivation of partial active centers. The M w as well as M w/M n of copolymers also indicated an interesting evolution as the copolymerization time increased. Acknowledgements The work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51473083), the National Basic Research Program of China (2015CB654700 (2015CB654706)), the Significant Basic Research Program of Shandong Province (ZR2017ZA0304) as well as Taishan Scholar Program. coredata.dc:description: Alkylaluminums as one of the most important components of the heterogeneous MgCl2-supported (TiCl4/MgCl2) type Ziegler-Natta catalysts, play significant roles in yielding active species with varied regio- and stereoselectivity. Studying the contribution of alkylaluminums on the conjugated diene isoprene (Ip) and butadiene (Bd) copolymerizations with TiCl4/MgCl2 - alkylaluminum catalysts system is little reported. In this work, effects of various alkylaluminums including triethylaluminium (TEA), triisobutylaluminium (TiBA), diisobutylaluminium hydride (DiBAH) and diethylaluminum chloride (DEAC) on the copolymerization behaviors of Ip and Bd using the TiCl4/MgCl2 - alkylaluminum catalysts system, such as catalytic activity, active center numbers, butadiene incorporation, trans-1,4 stereoselectivity, molecular weight M w as well as molecular weight distribution M w/M n of copolymers were first investigated. TEA with smaller size ethyl groups showed higher copolymerization activity, higher reducing ability and then yielding more active center numbers ([C*]/[Ti]) when compared with TiBA, DiBAH and DEAC. Microstructure of copolymers gradually transformed from the cis-1,4/trans-1,4 mixed structure in the initial polymerization period to the finally high trans-1,4 structure, indicating a transformation of the active center nature during the early polymerization stage, which can be accelerated effectively through the addition of DEAC into the TiCl4/MgCl2-TEA catalyst system. TEA with smaller size ethyl group showed higher transformation rate from the mixed structures of trans-1,4 and cis-1,4 to highly trans-1,4 structure. The active center numbers of the copolymerization systems increased gradually with increasing time until reaching a stable level. The M w/M n of copolymers showed interesting evolution with increasing polymerization time from broad distribution with low to medium molecular weight fractions in the initial polymerization stage to relatively narrow distribution with high molecular weight fractions. The contribution of alkylaluminium compounds on the structure of active species which determining the regio- and stereoselectivity of Ip and Bd copolymerization using heterogeneous TiCl4/MgCl2 type catalysts were discussed in details
coredata.dc:title: Effect of alkylaluminium on the regio- and stereoselectivity in copolymerization of isoprene and butadiene using TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalyst
